@dheavyside @NFT_Only @nftworldsNFT Iâ€™m interested in getting in on this but the only concern is isnâ€™t advertising not allowed based on Minecraftâ€™s EULA agreement? Iâ€™ve been trying to find answers around this but it still seems like itâ€™s not allowed?

It's inevitable that some owners will try to do this (some already talk about it). I think most don't know about EULA.

5/ In this web3 space dominated by text-based conversations, it is often difficult to read emotions. It is a reminder for us to acknowledge possible misunderstandings, which could be amplified by cultural differences. Nuances of words can change based on our personal experiences.

4/ He was "right" in a logical sense but he had failed to convince the team to take action on it, possibly because his ego lead to his constant insistence on being right. But other people were turned off by this behavior and could not take him seriously.
3/ He wasn't taken seriously back then and possibly felt aggrieved to take action against The DAO, by exploiting the vulnerabilities to net himself millions of dollars worth of crypto.

2/ An Austrian software developer was allegedly revealed to be the hacker behind the 2016 The DAO hack. Before the hack he had tried to warn the team about security vulnerabilities but his communication was "obnoxious (and) was quite insistent on having found a lot of problems."

1/ Fascinating story on the alleged hacker behind The DAO hack in 2016. I think this highlights the importance of cultivating emotional intelligence in a space full of talented and smart people. One may be "right" in logic but without consensus, situations cannot be made "right". https://t.co/wdv8VycLAD

@indigo03 You are right. But scarce land has value because it is self selective (through capital) to have the greatest likelihood to create content of value. Again, doesnâ€™t mean that abundant land has no value but the value is more in self-expression of the creator.

@nft_and_coffee Very good point. Scarce land helps to concentrate attention on a smaller area so itâ€™s more likely to create or foster social experiences in a way that is meaningful. Otherwise you might as well create a console game or an app.

@indigo03 There will be platforms providing unlimited land to give people a place to express their creativity and private events. And there is value in scarce land due to the benefit of â€œcuratedâ€ content (people who bought expensive land will more likely create content of value).

4/ Metaverse land can be infinite in theory, but people's attention is objectively scarce. You can build on infinite amounts of land but if no one visits it (or stops visiting after the initial novelty), are there other values beyond that of self-expression? Scarcity has value.

3/ The ability of NFTs to attract constant attention from the public is arguably one of the biggest contributors to NFT price. Projects that constantly execute and try to create value for holders may not necessary hold their value over time (especially with poor marketing).

2/ Biggest benefit of NFTs is to scale up communities rapidly to tap into strong network effects to collectively contribute to value growth, although other benefits like easier fundraising and greater market access for artists are also noteworthy benefits.

1/ Some shower thoughts on the following questions.

What's the biggest benefit of launching NFTs?
What's the biggest contributor to NFT price?
Should metaverse lands be scarce? 

These are my thoughts, summarized. If there are other opinions, I welcome people to challenge them.

@HappyCow1234 Personally I don't share the same opinion. If the team is new to NFTs or just want to focus on art they can always start with a much smaller collection to experiment. Otherwise a lot of people's investment is at stake. I say this after seeing a lot of such projects underperform.
@HappyCow1234 I take your point. But what if its no roadmap and don't plan to figure out. Main point is to sell 10K art pieces?

What's up with recent NFT projects that have no roadmap or even any plan? It makes me think that the founders either don't know about the benefits of NFTs to accelerate community building efforts, or they just can't be bothered. And yet they keep selling out.
